item.title: NHL RSN Situation: What You Need To Know
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
Every NHL season raises new questions regarding regional broadcasters and TV rights. If you live in a market affected by the league’s ongoing issues with regional sports networks (RSNs), here’s what you need to know about the best ways to watch local NHL games this season.

The post NHL RSN Situation: What You Need To Know appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Every NHL season raises new questions regarding regional broadcasters and TV rights. If you live in a market affected by the league’s ongoing issues with regional sports networks (RSNs), you may wonder if you can watch your team locally this season.

After the parent company of many RSNs emerged from bankruptcy, all Bally Sports channels rebranded as FanDuel Sports Network. Simultaneously, several NHL teams ditched the premium cable route entirely to strike deals with local broadcasters and establish their own streaming subscriptions. The good news is that despite all this chaos, in-market viewing options are still available for every single team.

Here’s what you need to know about the NHL RSN situation and the best ways to make sure you don’t miss the current NHL season.

Looking to catch NHL games on TV?

Check out our NHL watch guide and NHL on ESPN+ review for the best ways to stream every NHL game this season. Otherwise, enter your zip code below to browse TV providers in your area.

What channel is your local NHL team on?

Each NHL team has a local broadcast partner to carry games that don’t air nationally. Finding your local team can be confusing, especially with access varying between cable, streaming, and even antenna TV. That’s why we’ve created the table below, listing every team’s local TV affiliates.

If you’re unsure which team is considered “in-market” for you, the NHL has a great Broadcast Area Lookup tool where you can enter your zip code for a definitive answer. Of course, you’ll want to verify those details anytime you sign up for a TV service for RSN access.

The NHL’s shifting RSN landscape

RSNs have been in a tough spot in recent years. But two big moves created shockwaves for NHL teams and fans. In 2023, FanDuel Sports Network’s parent company entered bankruptcy, and Warner Bros. Discovery announced that it’d shut down its RSNs.

This instability has led to a fascinating new era of local NHL broadcasting. Some teams, like the Vegas Golden Knights and Utah Mammoth, have moved to a model of free over-the-air broadcasts paired with a direct-to-consumer (DTC) streaming service. Others, like the Pittsburgh Penguins, have even purchased their own RSN to ensure fans don’t miss a game.

So, what happens next? The situation is constantly evolving, but the NHL has been clear that it has backup plans in place. In a 2023 interview with The Athletic, NHL deputy commissioner Bill Daly said the league is “prepared to do what needs to be done” to ensure fans can watch local games.

Best local NHL TV providers

The best way to watch local NHL games really depends on your location and TV setup. We often recommend live TV streaming services like DIRECTV STREAM and Fubo because they carry most of the major RSNs with flexible plans. But you could go with a much cheaper option if your team offers its own DTC service, like Victory+ streaming all in-market Dallas Stars games for free to local fans.

Cable and satellite TV providers like Spectrum, Xfinity, and DIRECTV are still a valid way to get traditional RSNs. If you live in an area with spotty internet, a cable or satellite package is often your most reliable option.

For a much deeper dive into our top provider picks, specific package recommendations, and more viewing tips, check out our complete How To Watch the NHL guide.

Why you should trust us

This guide was created by our CableTV.com Internet Editor, Eric Chiu. To build it, he meticulously researched the local broadcast situation for all 32 NHL teams, tracking every RSN change and new broadcast deal from the previous season.

His analysis goes beyond just a simple channel list. It also examines how major shifts in the RSN landscape—like the Diamond Sports bankruptcy and the rise of direct-to-consumer streaming—are impacting the future of NHL media rights. The goal is to give you a clear, authoritative breakdown of a very confusing broadcast situation.

item.dc:creator: David Vick
item.description:
Will this season be a home run for the Mariners? Learn how to watch Seattle Mariners baseball with our guide, featuring their TV schedule and channel lineup.

The post How To Watch the 2025 Seattle Mariners Season appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
How hard is it to make the MLB playoffs when you play in the American League? Just ask the Seattle Mariners. Since 2001, they’ve had 11 winning seasons. Yet only one of those led to a playoff appearance.

But the Mariners managed to make 2025 a successful season and they’re continuing it in the postseason. They beat the Cleveland Guardians in the American League Divisional Series, and will face the Toronto Blue Jays in the Championship Series starting Sunday, October 12.

Even though the matchup and times of the ALDS are yet to be announced, I’ve put together a watch guide for this round of the playoffs and beyond with what we know so far. Keep checking back on this page as more information becomes available.

What channels have Seattle Mariners games?

ROOT SPORTS is the regional home for Seattle Mariners broadcasts in 2025. Apple TV+, ESPN, FOX, MLB Network, and The Roku Channel will also televise a handful of Mariners games.

Out-of-market fans who want to watch regional broadcasts this year will need MLB.TV or MLB EXTRA INNINGS to do so.

Want radio coverage? The Mariners Radio Network offers listening options to fans in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Alaska, and British Columbia. Fans in those states and Montana can also listen to games on the Seattle Sports 710 AM app or the Seattle Sports website.

Spanish-language audio is available for all Mariners home games through SAP channels on most of the cable and satellite providers that carry the ROOT SPORTS channel.

2025 Seattle Mariners playoffs TV schedule

After exorcising some two-decade-old demons, the Mariners are finally back in the American League Championship Series. They got here by winning a tough, five-game battle against the Tigers. That series saw Seattle claim its first home playoff victory since 2001.

Best TV plans for watching the Seattle Mariners

Mariners fans in the Pacific Northwest have two excellent viewing options for the 2025 MLB season: a direct-to-consumer (DTC) package or a standard TV provider. I’ll go over the positives of each to help make your viewing decision easier.

ROOT SPORTS Stream ($19.99/mo.)

If you think you need a cable or satellite subscription to watch the Mariners on TV in 2025, think again. ROOT SPORTS Stream—the exclusive DTC viewing option for local fans—broadcasts almost every game the Mariners will play this season. The monthly price is unbeatable, and you can watch games on the app or online while traveling outside the Mariners’ TV market for up to 30 days. This is what I call a winning deal!

Fubo ($14.99–$94.99/mo.)

Not many TV providers carry ROOT SPORTS in their channel lineup. Luckily, Fubo does. If you’re an in-market fan, all you need is a good internet connection and a compatible device to subscribe.

The main drawback to watching local Mariners games on a TV provider is the regional sports fee, and Fubo isn’t very transparent about this extra cost. Aside from that, there’s a lot to like about Fubo, including its unlimited recording capabilities. That comes in handy during a 162-game season.

How to watch the Seattle Mariners FAQ

Can I watch the Seattle Mariners for free?

Yes, you can watch the Seattle Mariners for free with an over-the-air antenna when games air on channels like FOX. Check out the FCC’s Reception Map Tool to find the channels that are available where you live.

Is ROOT SPORTS a regional sports network?

Yes, ROOT SPORTS is a regional sports network that provides coverage to fans in Washington, Oregon, Montana, Alaska, and parts of Idaho.

What channel is ROOT SPORTS on?

The channel that ROOT SPORTS is on depends on your TV provider and your location. Use the ROOT SPORTS Channel Finder tool to see which channel you can watch Mariners games on.

Where can I download the ROOT SPORTS Stream app?

You can download the ROOT SPORTS Stream app on Apple and Android devices, as well as several other streaming platforms and smart TVs.

Are the Mariners playing on Sunday Night Baseball in 2025?

Yes, the Mariners are playing on ESPN’s Sunday Night Baseball in 2025. They’ll be facing the Mets in the MLB Little League Classic on Sunday, August 17.

In professional sports, few things are more frustrating than unfulfilled potential, and Toronto Blue Jays fans have felt that sting more than once in recent years. Despite a talented core and multiple playoff appearances from 2015 to 2023, the team never managed to make a deep postseason run. Big expectations often turned into big letdowns.

Then came 2025, and the Blue Jays turned out to be one of the best teams in the Show.

Toronto won 94 games and earned a spot in the American League Championship Series. The Blue Jays will play the Seattle Mariners starting Sunday, October 12.

If you’re a Toronto fan who’s been itching to see if the Blue Jays can make a deep playoff run this year, I’ll show you how you can catch every playoff game on TV.

What channels have Toronto Blue Jays games?

How to watch in the United States

In the U.S., Toronto Blue Jays games are available out-of-market via MLB.TV, since U.S. viewers don’t fall within the Canadian blackout territory.

Nationally televised games (on channels like ESPN, FOX, FS1, and TBS) are available to U.S. fans via live TV providers or streaming services. But MLB.TV doesn’t include those live broadcasts.

How to watch in Canada

In Canada, the Toronto Blue Jays are exclusively broadcast through Sportsnet and its related feeds like Sportsnet One and Sportsnet 360. The network covers nearly every game throughout the regular season and postseason.

For French-speaking fans, TVA Sports (via a sub-licensing arrangement with Sportsnet) carries French-language broadcasts of Blue Jays games and some national MLB content in Canada.

Occasional Friday night Blue Jays games are exclusive to Apple TV+, which aren’t available through Sportsnet or Sportsnet+.

Want radio coverage? The Blue Jays’ flagship radio station is Sportsnet 590 The Fan (CJCL AM 590) in Toronto, with coverage available across southern Ontario. It simulcasts most games and is carried on satellite and digital platforms.

The Blue Jays finished the regular season as champions of the AL East for the first time since 2015, securing a first-round bye and home-field advantage. A subscription gives you access to nearly every regular-season Blue Jays game that isn’t nationally televised. Once subscribed, you can watch online or via the Sportsnet app on your preferred device.

Just don’t forget to add Apple TV+ to your setup if you want to catch the exclusive Friday Night Baseball games, which often feature the Blue Jays. That applies to fans in both Canada and the U.S.

United States: Get MLB.TV and a live TV service

For U.S.-based fans looking to watch the Toronto Blue Jays throughout the 2025 season, the most complete and convenient setup is a combination of MLB.TV and a live TV streaming service.

MLB.TV is the best way to watch nearly every Blue Jays game, since they’re considered an out-of-market team in the U.S. This means you can stream all regular-season games live or on demand, with the exception of those that air nationally on channels like ESPN or FOX.

To cover those national broadcasts, services like Fubo, DIRECTV, or Sling TV are your best bets.

  • Fubo: A top choice for sports fans, Fubo offers access to ESPN, FOX, FS1, and more, along with the option to integrate your MLB.TV subscription directly into the platform for a seamless viewing experience.
  • DIRECTV: DIRECTV’s streaming option also offers full access to national channels and supports MLB.TV as an add-on, making it a solid traditional alternative.
  • Sling TV: For a more budget-friendly approach, Sling TV with both the Orange and Blue packages plus the Sports Extra add-on gives you access to ESPN, TBS, FS1, and MLB Network. Keep in mind you’ll need to manage MLB.TV separately.

How can I watch the Toronto Blue Jays for free?

In the U.S., the best way to watch the Blue Jays is with MLB.TV, which includes nearly every out-of-market game. Pair it with Apple TV+ for Friday exclusives and a live TV service (like Fubo or Sling TV) for games on ESPN, FOX, FS1, or MLB Network. This combo ensures full-season coverage.

Why should American fans care about the only MLB team north of the border?

The Blue Jays feature a star-studded lineup with names like Vladimir Guerrero Jr. and Bo Bichette, plus they’re constant playoff contenders. Their games often feature thrilling matchups against top AL East rivals—and the newly renovated Rogers Centre is one of baseball’s most unique ballparks.

Can you stream NHL games?

Yes, you can stream over 1,000 NHL games each season on ESPN+—including every out-of-market matchup. Live TV streaming services also carry NHL channels, though not all regional sports networks are available through each provider.

Can you watch NHL on Amazon Prime?

No, you can’t watch NHL games on Amazon Prime Video except through its HBO Max and FanDuel Sports Network add-on channels. But as far as sports go, Prime Video does have Thursday Night Football and select MLB, NBA, NWSL, and WNBA matchups.

How can I watch all NHL games?

To watch every NHL game, you’ll need a combination of ESPN+, a TV service with national NHL channels, and your regional sports network for local NHL coverage.

Is NHL Network free?

No, NHL Network is not free, and you usually have to pay more to get it. NHL Network is available in most cable and satellite providers’ higher-priced plans, plus some live TV streaming services’ channel lineups—like DIRECTV, Fubo, and Sling TV.

How can I watch NHL games without cable?

You can watch select NHL games on ABC by using a digital antenna. Otherwise, as outlined in our NHL Without Cable guide, you can also catch NHL matchups on live TV streaming services. There’s also ESPN+, which carries exclusive matches and over 1,000 out-of-market games.

Where can I watch NHL preseason games?

Did NHL.TV go away?

NHL.TV is no longer available for users in the U.S. because ESPN+ is now the streaming home for out-of-market NHL games. Similarly, Sportsnet+ Premium (formerly Sportsnet NOW) replaced NHL LIVE for out-of-market access in Canada. These changes mean you can no longer use the NHL app to stream out-of-market games in the same way that MLB.TV or NBA League Pass work.

How can I listen to NHL games on the radio?

Most NHL teams have AM or FM radio affiliates for local fans to listen to live games. But you can also stream match audio from every NHL game this season on TuneIn Premium.

Cable TV comes through a cable. Satellite TV bounces from Earth to a satellite and back to a satellite dish on top of your house.

That said, Optimum’s TV plans do have some upsides. Optimum offers contract-free service, and its upper-tier TV plan is a bit more affordable than DIRECTV’s. But, with Optimum, your monthly payment rises sharply after the first year. At least you’re not locked into a contract.

But Optimum’s biggest cable TV downside—you can get it only with an Optimum internet subscription. Unfortunately, few cable internet providers offer standalone TV packages these days. If you don’t want internet, DIRECTV is the way to go.

One more downside: Optimum divides its TV plans between its two regions, meaning you’ll get different TV plan options depending on whether you live in Optimum’s East region (CT, NY, NJ) or its West region (everywhere else). Optimum vs. DIRECTV features

TV plans aren’t simply limited to your channels and monthly bill. Here’s everything else you’ll need to know about Optimum and DIRECTV service.

Equipment

DIRECTV wins here thanks to its superior Genie DVRs ($15 a month), which include up to 450 hours of DVR storage and 7 simultaneous recordings. DISH’s Hopper 3 DVR technically has better DVR features (500 hours, 16 simultaneous), but it also costs $10.00 monthly.

Optimum cable TV customers get one free Altice One Mini cable box, which includes 4K support and access to Optimum’s streaming TV apps. But if you want Cloud DVR service, you’ll need to pay an additional $8–$20 per month for up to 150 hours of storage.

Optimum’s DVR offerings fall in line with competitors like Xfinity and Spectrum. But Optimum’s free cable box offering is a nice add-on, since many providers will still charge you for your first cable box.

Customer satisfaction

DIRECTV took third place out of 10 providers in our annual TV customer satisfaction survey, thanks to its strong marks in areas like channel lineup and user experience. (Verizon finished in first place, while Spectrum, Xfinity, and Cox tied for second.)

By comparison, Optimum earned a dismal 8th-place overall finish and consistently landed in the bottom half of our polling among providers like Astound. When customers had problems with Optimum, things didn’t tend to go well.

Internet service

Optimum landed in a similarly dismal 16th place (out of 21 providers) on our internet customer satisfaction survey. Optimum customers weren’t fans of the provider’s average speeds and customer support.

DIRECTV doesn’t offer internet service, so your options will be wide open if you want to bundle DIRECTV with an internet plan. Enter your zip code below to see what internet options are available in your neighborhood.

Final take

Even though DIRECTV is a bit pricier than Optimum, we’d still recommend the satellite TV provider over Optimum for most households. With DIRECTV, you’ll get better customer service, robust channel lineups, and a superior DVR.

That said, if you’re also looking for a new internet provider, Optimum’s solid internet and TV bundles (with great deals to boot) are hard to turn down. But, the provider’s lackluster customer service is one of its biggest downsides.

DIRECTV vs. Optimum FAQ

Is DIRECTV better than cable?

DIRECTV is better than cable in some areas. It has more sports channels compared to cable TV providers, but its prices are generally larger than cable TV providers. But on satellite TV providers like DIRECTV, you may experience signal loss during heavy storms or major weather events.

Does Optimum use satellite dishes?

Optimum does not use satellite dishes because it’s a cable TV provider. Cable TV providers deliver their signal through in-ground cables.

Can I negotiate with Optimum?

You can negotiate with Optimum, although you’re not guaranteed to successfully land a better deal. Check out our bill negotiation guide for the best ways to get a new deal from Optimum.

Is Optimum the same as DIRECTV?

Optimum is not the same as DIRECTV. Optimum and DIRECTV are two different TV providers.
